newsitem.title: USA: New England states seek federal disaster declared.
newsitem.headline: New England states seek federal disaster declared.

text.p: Three New England governors turned to Washington Wednesday for federal help in coping with damage caused by a powerful storm that swept up the U.S. East Coast earlier this week.
The governors of Massachusetts, Maine and New Hampshire have requested that President Bill Clinton declare at least part of their states federal disaster areas.
Thousands of homes and businesses that suffered storm damage in the three states are inland and not covered by flood insurance.
The governors were waiting for state and Federal Emergency Management Agency teams to complete their assessments of the damages before formally seeking a declaration from Clinton.

"If the president declares the area a disaster area, then those people that don't have flood insurance will be covered," said Jim Rivers, a spokesman for New Hampshire Gov. Stephen Merrill, who is expected to seek relief for at least eight of the state's 10 counties by the end of the week.
Rivers estimated that damage in New Hampshire, which has four electoral votes, will reach $4 million to $6 million at least.
In Massachusetts, where officials expect damage estimates to soar, Gov. William Weld sent a letter to President Clinton late Tuesday asking for a federal disaster declaration.
"I'm saying multimillion dollars," David Rodham of the state's public safety department, said Wednesday.

In Boston, the city is estimating $11 million in damages. while the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which operates the subways, is estimating $15 million, Rodham said. In the city of Quincy, at least 1,000 homes have suffered major damage, he said.
